## Title

> Please provide a name for your action learning plan.

Youth Unemployment
## Challenge statement

> Challenge type: If you are working on multiple challenges, please indicate if this is your "big bet" or "exploratory" challenge. 

Please note: we ask you to only submit a maximum of 3 challenges - 1x Big Bet, 2x Exploratory. Each challenge must be submitted individually.


> Challenge statement: What is your challenge? (Please answer in specific terms: "Our challenge is that...”.)

Our challenge is that Pacific island Countries have a young population, with high rates of unemployment amongst youth.&nbsp;

> Background: What is the history of your challenge? What is causing or driving it? Who is involved? How does the current situation look like? What undesired effects does it produce?

<p class="MsoNormal" style="line-height:150%"><span lang="EN-US" style="font-family:
Lora">The Pacific Island Countries experience significant unemployment and
under employment, especially amongst youth. This is particularly concerning as
Pacific populations are young, with a recorded 18% of the population between
the ages of 15 – 24 years old in 2021. While comparative data on Pacific labour
markets is sparse and shifting definitions of employment and unemployment have
made it difficult to assess labour market trends, the International Labour
Organisation (ILO) has estimated that 23% of youth in the Pacific are
unemployed. This statistic rises even further in some Pacific Island Countries.
In Vanuatu approximately 43% of youth (15-24 years) without disabilities are
not in education, employment, or training, as of 2019, and 87% for youth living
with disabilities. <o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="line-height:150%"><span lang="EN-US" style="font-family:
Lora">Pacific Island Countries also face unique challenges such as
vulnerability to natural hazards, remoteness from major markets, small
economies and are geographically dispersed. These challenges hinder development
progress, and often results in more pressing development challenges such as
recovery post-disaster, food, water and shelter being given priority in terms
of allocation of resources and budgets, over other development challenges such
as youth unemployment.&nbsp;&nbsp;<o:p></o:p></span></p>

> Quantitative evidence: What (official) data sources do you have on this challenge that better exemplifies the importance and urgency of this frontier challenge? You can add text, a link, or a picture.


<div class="group">


> 

https://www.spc.int/updates/blog/did-you-know/2022/12/stat-of-the-week-in-vanuatu-87-of-youth-with-disabilities-are-not<div><img src="data:image/png;base64," alt=""><br></div>


</div>


> Qualitative evidence: What weak signals have you recently spotted that characterizes its urgency? Please provide qualitative information that better exemplifies the importance and urgency of this frontier challenge. You can add text, a link, or a picture.


<div class="group">


> 

Youth unemployment leads to Pacific Islanders seeking work in other countries which leads to a skills brain drain for Pacific Island Countries. Some emerging signals being sensed is that the skills drain is leading to an increase of demand for expat workers, which drives up cost of living (housing costs) which is an added financial burden on locals who then begin to move further from the city areas.<div>Academically qualified youth often face challenges securing work as they do not meet the required work experience.</div><div><br></div>


</div>


> Value proposition: What added value or unique value proposition is your Accelerator Lab bringing to solving this challenge? Why is it your Lab that needs to work on this challenge and not other actors within UNDP, other stakeholders in the country respectively? Why is it worth investing resources to this challenge?

<span lang="EN-US" style="font-size:11.0pt;line-height:
107%;font-family:Lora;mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-theme-font:
minor-latin;mso-bidi-font-family:Arial;mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-bidi;
mso-ansi-language:EN-US;mso-fareast-language:EN-US;mso-bidi-language:AR-SA">To
create a more sustainable economic environment that is resilient to the
challenges faced by Pacific communities and future shocks, the UNDP Pacific
Office in Fiji is aiming to establish a Pacific Youth Hub. The purpose of the
Youth Hub is to support the empowerment of existing and new youth-generated
initiatives. The Youth Hub will create an enabling environment where the skills
and talents of youth are nurtured and cultivated and will allow for the formation
of increased&nbsp;<span lang="EN-US" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 107%;">opportunities
in early career, self-employment and entrepreneurship.&nbsp;</span>&nbsp;</span>

> Short “tweet” summary: We would like to tweet what you are working on, can you summarize your challenge in a maximum of 280 characters?

UNDP Pacific Office in Fiji is working with key stakeholders to establish a Youth Hub to support the empowerment of existing and new youth-generated initiatives. The Youth Hub aims to create opportunities in early career, self-employment and entrepreneurship.&nbsp;

## Learning questions

> Learning question: What is your learning question for this challenge? What do you need to know or understand to work on your challenge statement?

Can setting up a youth hub help to increase capacity building and employment opportunities for youth?

> To what stage(s) in the learning cycle does your learning question relate?

- Explore
- Test

> Usage of methods: Relating to your choice above, how will you use your methods & tools for this learning question? What value do these add in answering your learning question?

These methods will ensure the experimented solution (youth hub) is co-designed, sustainable, and locally owned in the long term.

> Existing data gaps: Relating to your choice above, what existing gaps in data or information do these new sources of data addressing? What value do these add in answering your learning question?

These data sources will support a participatory approach to the development of a youth hub, and ensure it is relevant to the local context and sustainable.
## Closing

> Early leads to grow: Think about the possible grow phase for this challenge - who might benefit from your work on this challenge or who might be the champions in your country that you should inform or collaborate with early on to help you grow this challenge?

Youth<div>Govt</div><div>Private Sector</div><div>NGOs/ CSOs</div>
